author: Angela Moore
title: Parents: Your camp counselor may be expecting a tip
text:
There’s a debate raging among parents as the summer draws to a close. In some quarters, it rises to the level of the Hatfield and McCoys , crunchy vs. smooth peanut butter, or whether you prefer the Beatles or the Stones.
Should you tip camp counselors?
Some parents were shocked by the suggestion.
“It never occurred to me to tip because I wasn’t tipped,” said Tanya Keith, a mother in Des Moines, Iowa, who sent two of her children to camp. She worked as a camp counselor growing up and never received tips, although she would occasionally get a small gift from a camper who developed a bond with her. “We’re supposed to be tipping camp counselors?”
Moms I spoke with in Maryland, Massachusetts and New Jersey were also incredulous.
“I never thought to tip a counselor. Is this necessary?” asked Samantha Freitag of New Jersey. “When is someone going to tip me?”

Other parents considered it part of the overall cost of camp, or a token of appreciation.
“I do tip. The counselors depend on it as part of their salary for the summer,” said Jen Lavie, a New Jersey mom. “Sort of like waiters depend on tips. The head counselor gets more than the junior. I usually poll friends and find out what they’re tipping so I stay in line.”
Ashley DiGeronimo received gratuities from parents when she was a camp counselor and now tips as a parent. “I did not depend on parent tips but [they] sure helped supplement the weekly pay,” she said. “Not all of the counselors were expecting to get tipped but they definitely appreciated the added touch.”
“I can see how some parents would be annoyed with the suggestion of tipping, but as a former counselor, I know how hard these folks work, and Lord knows it isn’t the counselors who receive most of the tuition,” said one New York mom who did not want to be named and plans to tip her children’s counselors. “So does it bother me? No.”
